Description: Typical range for 1064 nm pulsed lasers in stone cleaning to avoid thermal damage to granite's low thermal conductivity (~1.5 W/m·K); starting at 100W for light contamination. Max safe below granite's damage threshold (~400°C melting point onset). Source: IPG Photonics YLR series specs and study in Optics and Lasers in Engineering (2018) on stone ablation.
Near-infrared wavelength optimized for granite mineral absorption
Beam spot diameter for precise cleaning control
Optimal repetition rate for efficient cleaning coverage
Nanosecond pulse duration for effective contaminant removal with minimal substrate damage
Optimal scanning speed for uniform cleaning coverage
Recommended number of passes for complete contaminant removal
Optimal beam overlap for uniform cleaning without excessive thermal buildup
